heading: 2 Study Premise
text:
Project MAXED (Phase 1: 2020-) study conducting investigation exercise response among girls young women eating disorders developed EMBARK lab 2020.1.1 Specific Aims:
Driven exercise serious common feature eating disorders, current understanding factors give rise maintain driven exercise limited. Project MAXED aims evaluate acute psychobiological response bout moderate-intensity exercise among young females (age 14-22 years) without mild--moderate eating disorder symptoms. Overall, study contribute conceptualization driven exercise individuals’ acute biological affective responses exercise contribute risk maintenance driven exercise. pilot study two primary aims:Aim 1: Confirm feasibility paradigms evaluating acute response exercise among outpatient individuals mild--moderate eating disorder symptoms. confirm feasibility exercise-based tasks via ) study dropout timepoints, b) adverse events, c) completion rates study tasks. course study, expect eating disorder healthy control groups meet thresholds < 20% dropout, zero adverse events, > 80% task completion.Aim 2: Characterize variability biobehavioral response -lab exercise among individuals mild--moderate eating disorders. characterize changes exercise state body image, mood, biological markers eating disorder healthy control groups; specifically characterize mean levels , variability , biobehavioral response exercise across groups.

heading: 3 Procedures
text: first wave study include recruitment 40 (20 control 20 participants ED symptoms) female adolescents young adults aged 14-22.

heading: 3.1 Recruitment
text: Recruitment sources include: (1) University Health Services UW-Madison area colleges universities (2) flyers area businesses (e.g. fitness centers, coffee shops) (3) local mental health providers, including providers within Wisconsin Psychiatric Institute Clinic (WisPIC), well outside UW settings (e.g., Community Mental Health Centers, private practices, etc.) (4) online advertisement social media platforms (5) direct, peer--peer recruitment peer facilitators, (6) campus e-mail recruitment.

heading: 4 Interventions
text: 2 stages protocol: 1) Screening Day screening assessments; 2) Day , DayB, Day C consist computational exercise tasks, questionnaires, blood draw. Participants complete two stages across 4 separate days. Day , Day B, Day C occur randomly, spaced 6-8 days apart.

heading: 4.1 Screening Day stage
text: Screening Day stage, participants undergo structured clinical interview assess current eating disorder symptoms, psychological symptoms,cognitive function assessment, physical status, demographics. participants 18 years old, parents also asked complete demographics form. Participants also complete Approach Avoidance Conflict task. assessment stage lasts 3-4 hours.

heading: 4.2 Day A, DayB, and Day C Stage
text: Day , participants complete two different tasks–Task 1: “Reward task” (rest condition) include self-report measures, two blood draws immediately completing 30 minutes rest examine changes key neurotransmitters time, post-rest behavioral task; Task 2: “Threat task”(active condition) include self-report state emotional, body image, behavioral urges cravings,food challenge task drinking milkshake, 30 minutes exercise. Day B, participants complete Task 1: Reward (active condition), includes self-report questionnaires, behavioral task participants work earn “points” exercise, two blood draws, including one immediately one immediately completing 30 minutes exercise examine changes key neurotransmitters. Day C, participants complete Task 2: Threat (rest condition),include completion self-report questionnaires, food challenge task, 30 minutes rest. Participants provide four blood samples total study. order ensure blood monoamine hormone levels controlled, participants asked refrain eating after1:00pm, eating provided nutritional supplement (nutrition bar) snack attending Day Day B study visits 4pm. Additionally, Task Day B scheduled follicular phase control possible menstrual phase effects biological response exercise. Menstrual phase clarified controlled collection blood samples Task Day B quantify estradiol levels. Participants also complete reinforcement learning task following Day Day B examine acute impact exercise reinforcement learning mechanisms. Day , Day B, Day C last 2 hours. Lastly, participants provided fitness tracker wear for7 days screening visit second visit objectively determine average levels physical activity.

heading: 5.2 Childhood Trauma Questionnaire (CTQ)
text:
Scoring Childhood Trauma Questionnaire developed David Bernstein colleagues includes 28-item self-report measure (Berstein, et al., 1998). CTQ designed examine traumatic childhood experiences adults adolescents. Questions focus traumatic experiences examples abuse neglect (ie. ctq_not_enough_to_eat, ctq_parents_drunk_high, etc.). Items scored Likert scale 1 (never true) 5 (often true). High scores indicate trauma (Wright et al., 2001).Scoring

heading: 5.4 Intolerance of Uncertainty (IUS)
text:
Scoring Intolerance Uncertainty Scale developed Freeston, Rhéaume, Letarte, Dugas, Ladouceur (1994) 27 item survey assess Intolerance Uncertainty (IU). Intolerance Uncertainty Scale (IUS) assesses reaction four main ideas: uncertainty stressful upsetting, uncertainty leads inability act, uncertain events negative avoided, uncertain unfair (Buhr, K, et al., 2001). consists two factors: prospective anxiety (.e. “can’t stand taken surprise”) inhibitory anxiety (.e. “must get away uncertain situations”). Items rated 5-point Likert type scale 1 (“characteristic ”) 5 (“Entirely characteristic ”). Degree intolerance determined finding sum total answers. High scores indicate greater IU.Scoring

heading: 5.7 BIS/BAS Scale
text: BIS/BAS Scale 24-item self-report questionnaire designed C.S. Carver T.L. White. scale designed measure two motivational systems: behavioral inhibition system (BIS), corresponds motivation avoid aversive outcomes, behavioral activation system (BAS), corresponds motivation approach goal-oriented outcomes. Participants respond item using 4-point Likert scale: 1 (true ), 2 (somewhat true ), 3 (somewhat false ), 4 (false ).ScoringKey Variables

heading: 5.13 Functions of Exercise Scale (FOE)
text: Functions Exercise Scale developed Patricia Marten DiBartolo, Linda Lin, Simone Montoya, Heather Neal, Carey Shaffer. scale includes two subscales: Weight Appearance (WA), Health Enjoyment (). FES 16-item, self-report questionnaire assesses motivation exercise. Individuals provide ratings using 7-item scale “1 = agree” “7 = strongly agree”. FES-scores positively correlated psychological well-physical health. Conversely, FES-WA scores negatively correlated depressive eating disorder symptoms, self-esteem, physical well-.ScoringKey Variables
